review_text: I was still in a sci-fi mood after my last read but also wanted something on the shorter side. This was awesome, introducing an immediately likeable lead while packing in cool world-building, creepy tension, and exciting action scenes, all within about 150 pages. I immediately clicked with the main character's vibe, a deadly for-hire security robot that's secretly overridden its company's ability to control it, primarily using that freedom to quietly binge-watch television dramas during its downtime. The writing has a lot of fun with character's mindset, with the robot mildly annoyed by and uncomfortable around the humans it still genuinely wants to protect. Highly enjoyable! I'll certainly come back for more. 1 like

Blöd nur, dass es sich ungeahnt empathisch dabei anstellt, als es zwei Klient*innen davor rettet, von einem besonders gefräßigen Alien zu Tode gemampft zu werden. Jetzt wollen einige Menschen mit SecUnit sprechen. Am Ende noch mit Blickkontakt. Der pure Horror! (Leute, ich hab die Reihe jetzt bis auf den letzten halben Band am Stück weggesuchtet … ich habe zu wenig geschlafen und fühle mich, als hätte ich einen nicht geringen Anteil meiner Hirnkapazität gespacet und habe mich beim Schreiben dieser Review in einen regelrechten Buchstabenrausch geschrieben. Ich entschuldige mich jetzt schon für meinen Redeschwall. Unten einmal meine Gedanken zur gesamten Buchreihe, dann kann ich mich in den folgenden Reviews kurz zu den Einzelbänden äußern. tl;dr: Die Buchreihe ist klasse. Selten so begeistert gewesen.) Diese Buchreihe wurde mir von zwei Freundinnen unabhängig voneinander wärmstens ans Herz gelegt und … siehattensorechtdiesesBuchistdasbesteseitgeschnittenBrotlestesalleesistsogutaaaaahhhh!!!! Lasst mich nicht anfangen zu schwärmen, sonst bekomme ich einen Laberanfall der Sonderklasse und erzähle euch ungefragt und szenengenau ausführlich, warum die ganze Murderbot-Reihe das Beste ist, was ich seit Monaten gelesen habe. *luftholt* Ich war langsam schon genervt davon, dass ich so viel Romance lese, obwohl ich auf die ganzen Sexszenen üblicherweise nicht mal besonderen Wert lege. Ich fürchtete, dass ich vielleicht einfach verdumme und auf seichte Lektüre stehe oder so. Aber nein, die Murderbot-Diaries haben mir gezeigt, warum ich sowas eigentlich lese und was ich darin suche. Ich habe sie endlich gefunden – die garantiert absolut sex- und romantikfreie Buchreihe, die ALL THE FEEELINGS und ALL THE INTERESTING AND LIKEABLE CHARACTERS erkundet! Wer hätte es geahnt … Emotionen und Beziehungen sind so viel vielschichtiger als immer nur LiebeLiebeLiebe und dadurch, dass wir hier einem künstlichen Konstrukt folgen, das schon rein biologisch nullkommanull Interesse an dieser Art von Fortpflanzung hat, bleibt endlich der Raum, sich mit allem anderen zu befassen. Und es ist mindestens genauso spannend, verwirrend, aufregend, mitreißend, einfühlsam, beängstigend, herzerwärmend und herzzerreissend, zuzusehen, wie hier die Menschen, Konstrukte, Bots miteinander agieren. ALL THE DRAMA! Ein anderer Punkt – ich habe lange keinen Charakter gelesen, mit dem ich mich so sehr identifizieren konnte wie mit SecUnit/Murderbot, wenn es keinen Bock mehr auf Menschen hat, ohne dabei Menschen grundsätzlich zu hassen. Nicht, dass ich mich mit dem Gesicht zur Wand drehen würde, aber ich kann das Bedürfnis danach gut nachempfinden und direkter Blickkontakt während eines nicht-intimen Gesprächs ist die Geißel der Menschheit, wenn ihr mich fragt (ich wünschte, *ich* könnte mir eine Subroutine coden, die mich die gesellschaftlich erwünschte Menge an Augenkontakt automatisch halten lässt, während ich mein Blickfeld aktiv ignoriere und meine Gesprächspartner*innen im Livestream über meine Drohnenkamera anschaue). Und nein, ich wüsste nicht, dass ich autistisch bin. Aber ich glaube, dass viele Menschen, die zur Introvertiertheit und allgemeiner sozialer Unsicherheit neigen, in SecUnit einen sehr nachempfindbaren Charakter finden. Es ist aber sicher auch kein Zufall, dass so viele Autist*innen sich mit SecUnit identifizieren können. Ich habs auch sooo gefühlt, als SecUnit nach einem richtig beschissenen Tag einfach nur auf seinem ungemütlichen Plastikbett crashen und Serien schauen will. Ich gucke wenig Serien, aber ersetze geistig „Serie schauen“ durch „gutes Buch lesen“ und schon bin ich dabei. Hey, ich habe definitiv Buchreihen, die mein Sanctuary Moon sind und aus denen ich Abschnitte auswendig rezitieren kann, um mich in Stresssituationen abzuregen. Feel you, SecUnit, feel you. Was ich auch großartig finde – Ich liebe es, Geschichten über kompetente Charaktere zu lesen. Und abseits aller social awkwardness – wenns um seinen Job geht, ist SecUnit wirklich überdurchschnittlich kompetent. Das ist SO befriedigend, wenn es sich durch Systeme hackt, schnelle und fundierte Entscheidungen trifft, Abwägungen macht, Wahrscheinlichkeiten berechnet, Leute entwaffnet und Dinge zerschlägt. SO! Befriedigend! In diesem Zusammenhang: Ich lese sonst nicht gerne SciFi-Technobabble. Oft steht er in Verbindung mit langen Beschreibungen von technischen Geräten oder astronomisch-physikalischen Erklärungen, die mich einfach nicht interessieren. In dieser Buchreihe ist der Technobabble eher im IT-Bereich angesiedelt und auch da reicht ein halbwegs oberflächliches Verständnis davon, wie ein Code oder ein Netzwerk grundsätzlich funktionieren, um folgen zu können. Ich bin Historikerin, nicht ITlerin – wenn ich das schaffe, schafft ihr das auch! Ich habe dank der Murderbot-Reihe zum ersten Mal verstanden, warum Leute sowas gerne lesen. Es war gar nicht anstrengend, sondern absolut mühelos und aber ich hatte gleichzeitig das Gefühl, total *smort* zu sein und alles voll zu durchschauen. Wieder: SO! Befriedrigend! Ich liebe es, dass das Aussehen der Personen recht spärlich beschrieben wird. Selbst von unserer Hauptfigur SecUnit erfahren wir im Verlauf der Bände nur vage Informationen zum Äußeren, abseits von „in langen Klamotten siehts wie ein Mensch mit Dataport im Nacken aus“. Das gelingt in anderen Büchern nicht so gut, aber hier werden die Figuren über ihr Verhalten, ihre Art zu sprechen und ihre Beziehungen untereinander so gut charakterisiert, dass das Aussehen so weit in den Hintergrund tritt, dass es tatsächlich so egal ist, wie es sein sollte. Davon abgesehen lese ich ohnehin nicht gern lange Beschreibungen vom Aussehen, weil ich insbesondere Frisuren und Klamotten auch einfach nicht sehr interessant finde. Urban Fantasy und Romance sind voll von solchen Beschreibungen und es könnte mir nicht egaler sein, welche Jeans die Figur heute trägt. Die Murderbot-Diaries entlasten hier meinen Arbeitsspeicher beim Lesen, indem das beschrieben wird, was ich wissen will. Und nicht das, was die Autorin oder der Autor meinen, mir unbedingt vermitteln zu müssen, damit ich mir alles richtig™ vorstelle. Naja und dann sind die gesellschaftlichen und sozialen Verhältnisse angenehm und unaufdringlich dargestellt. Verschiedene romantische Beziehungen der Menschen gehören zu deren Hintergründen, werden aber nicht tiefer thematisiert oder als Besonderheit herausgestellt. Das verleiht ihnen gebührende Selbstverständlichkeit und lässt – wieder – Platz für weitere, interessante Aspekte. Ok, wir wissen, dass Dr. Mensah zwei Ehepartner*innen und einige Kinder zuhause hat. Das ist cool – aber ist nicht ihr einziger definierender Faktor, denn rein zufällig ist sie außerdem politische Entität, wissenschaftliche Fachfrau und eine energische Anführerin. Und nicht frei von Fehlern. Insbesondere konzentriert sich die ganze Buchreihe - neben der formidablen Action - auf die Frage, wer SecUnit ist und was es will vom Leben. Damit in Verbindung stehen Fragen danach, was es überhaupt ausmacht, eine Person zu sein, wie eine Person behandelt werden sollte, welche Rechte wem gebühren. Wer über wen bestimmen darf und was das jeweils impliziert. Steht natürlich, abseits der SciFi auch damit in Verbindung, was uns als Menschen ausmacht und wie wir miteinander umgehen sollten. Ich sehe realweltlich durchaus auch Parallelen zu Tierrechtsdebatten, aber jetzt schweife ich endgültig ab. Ah, ich könnte ewig so weiterschwärmen! Ähm ja. Also, man merkt es kaum, aber ich bin restlos begeistert und fahre einen serotoningeschwängerten Lektüretrip der Sonderklasse. Vielleicht lese ich die Reihe, wenn ich durch bin, auch einfach nochmal von vorne, bis im Mai der nächste Band erscheinen soll. So. *geht weiterlesen* 2 likes

Martha Wells' "All Systems Red" introduces readers to Murderbot, a security unit that has hacked its governor module to gain autonomy. Despite its newfound freedom, Murderbot prefers to binge-watch media and avoid human interaction. However, it's stuck with a team of scientists on a survey mission on a distant planet. The story is told from Murderbot's cynical and introverted point of view, offering a unique perspective on the interactions between humans and AI. As the team explores the planet, they discover evidence of a previous, failed expedition and soon realize they are not alone. The character development in "All Systems Red" is one of the strongest aspects of the novella. Murderbot is a fascinating and relatable protagonist, despite being an AI construct. Its internal monologue is filled with sarcasm, anxiety, and a surprising amount of empathy. The human characters are also well-drawn, each with their own distinct personalities and motivations. The relationship between Murderbot and the scientists evolves throughout the story, as they gradually come to trust and rely on each other. One of the major plot twists involves the revelation that the previous expedition was deliberately sabotaged, leading to a deadly confrontation with a rival corporation. The tone of "All Systems Red" is a blend of action, humor, and introspection. Wells expertly balances the fast-paced plot with moments of quiet reflection, allowing readers to delve into Murderbot's complex inner world. The novella is filled with witty banter and sarcastic observations, providing plenty of laughs along the way. However, it also explores deeper themes about identity, freedom, and the nature of humanity. Thematically, "All Systems Red" explores the question of what it means to be human, even for a non-human entity. Murderbot's struggle to understand its own emotions and motivations is a central theme of the story. The novella also touches on issues of corporate greed, environmental exploitation, and the ethics of artificial intelligence. Ultimately, "All Systems Red" is a story about finding connection and purpose in a hostile universe. In conclusion, "All Systems Red" is a thrilling and thought-provoking novella that offers a fresh take on the science fiction genre. Martha Wells has created a memorable protagonist in Murderbot, and the story is filled with action, humor, and heart. For readers who enjoy "All Systems Red," I recommend "A Fire Upon the Deep" by Vernor Vinge, which also features complex AI characters and epic space battles, and "The Martian" by Andy Weir, which combines scientific accuracy with a compelling survival story. read-before-watching

Reading All Systems Red felt like slipping into the mind of someone who’s already given up on being understood. Murderbot’s voice is sardonic, numb, and strangely heartbreaking — a creature built for violence, wired for obedience, yet quietly desperate to disappear into the comforting static of its media feeds. The isolation hits hardest: it moves through the world surrounded by people it’s meant to protect, yet it never believes it belongs beside them. That loneliness, wrapped in humor sharp enough to border on self-defense, makes the story feel less like sci-fi adventure and more like a confession from someone who never asked to exist. What lingers isn’t the danger the characters face but the way Murderbot constantly assumes the worst of itself. Every time it steps between humans and harm, there’s this sense of weary inevitability — like it’s bracing for the moment its usefulness runs out. Its internal monologue reads like someone trying to shrink out of their own story, terrified of being seen, yet unable to stop caring in the small, reluctant ways that hurt the most. Even when the plot accelerates into tense survival, that low thrum of self-loathing never really fades; it just hides under the action beats. By the end, the book doesn’t offer comfort so much as a grim acknowledgment of what it means to keep going when connection feels dangerous and identity feels like a wound. The story is short, almost brutally so, and it leaves you with the sense that Murderbot’s journey is far from healing — it’s merely the first step of someone who knows freedom won’t magically make them whole. And maybe that’s what makes this little novella so quietly devastating: beneath the armor, the algorithms, and the dry humor, Murderbot feels painfully human in its desire to stay unseen… and its inability to stop caring anyway. 1 like

This novella felt like a spin-off story in a much larger series — the world is fully developed and richly realized, and the audience is just expected to get it. I felt like I understood about 75% of what was going on most of the time. I know that was an intentional choice, but it’s not one I like very much. I prefer it when I get to discover the world as the story progresses. Minor spoilers ahead. The other major problem was that every character except for Murderbot was cardboard. None of them had any distinguishable personalities, and I could barely tell them apart. I slowly began to parse their individual identities by the end, but then Murderbot leaves them. So what was the point? Murderbot’s declaration that Mensah was his favorite human at the end just rang hollow. For this whole novel, we’re in Murderbot’s head. Martha Wells is very good at portraying his internal struggle and development, and Murderbot’s character arc is what drives this novella and makes it worth reading. BUT, I think that’s also why the other characters fell so flat. Clearly Wells is good at characterization, but with such a strict point of view, she constricts herself. Because of the lack of visible character development for the human characters, the actual plot fell extremely flat for me too. Why should I care about what’s going on with the weird planet when Murderbot doesn’t? The climax is somewhat interesting, but only because Murderbot has a personal stake in it. Murderbot also warms up to the humans VERY quickly. At the start, they don’t care about the crew at all, but about an hour in they’re extremely protective of them? It didn’t make much sense. I think the idea is that these humans are the first to show genuine compassion toward them, which is great in concept, except that Murderbot previously stated that they didn’t care what the humans thought of them at all. This is part of a much larger issue, though; this novella should have been a full-length novel. Just about every aspect of this book needed more elaboration and more development. Murderbot is very relatable, very funny, and extremely compelling. I absolutely love their arc in this book — they learned that to truly find yourself, you need compassion and determination. Mensah and her crew showed them compassion, and because of that they had the determination to do what was good. They still don’t know who they are, but they know what it means to be sentient. And that is a beautiful character arc, which sets up their further development wonderfully. And in a way, this could be interpreted as a story about how powerful fiction is and the impact it has on the psyche. Murderbot learns a lot about how to live well by watching media. The issue is that we don’t get much of any description of the media they watch, but still. It’s nice. This was a good book, but not quite as good as everyone says. After watching the show, it’s abundantly clear that this novella needed to be a novel; all the elements of greatness are here (interesting characters, fun plot, emotional character arcs, etc.), but Wells basically speed-runs the whole story in 150 pages. If it was 200 pages longer, it would have been a masterpiece. As it is, it’s just okay. Also, the constant use of “it” as a single pronoun felt so odd to me. Even after the crew found out that Murderbot was sentient, they still used “it.” This is a queer-normative world, just use “they”! I know Murderbot doesn’t care, but Murderbot isn’t a thing. They’re a person. Use a pronoun that befits a person. Also, why the hell would he choose “Murdebot” as a name? Just because it’s funny? If that is the reason, why wouldn’t they change their name at the end of the story once they have a more serious view of their own sentience? It just doesn’t make much sense. 2025 queer science-fiction 1 like

I love science fiction, and I see mentions of this series all the time, so I’m not sure why it took me so long to read it. I definitely had the perception that it would be fairly dark, so maybe it was that. At any rate, it was completely different from what I was anticipating. My biggest issue, frankly, is the length, and that’s really only to say that I enjoyed it enough that I wished it were longer. I went into it not realizing it was written as a novella, so that likely colored my reaction. The world-building is really interesting, but it does feel introductory. The world we’re presented with is pretty dark – this is a system with very little care or empathy (on an uninhabited planet, there’s an expectation that equipment is poorly made) and there are references to deeply questionable treatment of the not-entirely-human – but my understanding of the world is pretty limited, and I’m left with a lot of questions. Since this is a series, I’m happy that I’ll get to dive back into this world and learn more. This is a really fun, quick read that made me laugh out loud multiple times, which I wasn’t expecting. The tone is everything here. Murderbot is a new favorite character; its voice is delightfully droll and its thought processes are interesting, concrete, and at times, hilarious. The characterization, for me, steals the spotlight because Wells manages to balance Murderbot’s humor with its tragic background and place in the world. I love that the novella is thought-provoking without feeling preachy or pulling the reader from the story while also delivering some great comedy. Perhaps because I listened to this on audio, I did have some difficulty with keeping the rest of the characters straight. They were all well imagined, and by the end I felt I knew a few, but I would have liked some additional development so they all felt clearer earlier in the story. This was also a really quick read (so quick that I verified twice that I hadn’t inadvertently chosen the abridged audiobook before realizing that it’s a novella 😂), and the plot moved at warp speed. I love a fast-moving story, but again I felt some additional development wouldn’t have gone awry. The mystery was solved in a fairly mundane way when I’d hoped there would be a little more to it. The ending also felt a little rushed. Overall, I really enjoyed this one and look forward to reading more in the series. audio science-fiction

This element hangs over the first half of the narrative, supposing to be some mysterious inciting event, but is revealed and discussed in its entirety in about two sentences. The ongoing mystery throughout had such cool potential, but again is revealed with no fanfare or further discussion. The reveal didn’t even really seem all that important. I’m given the facts of why I should care about these things, but the way they are presented had almost no emotional impact on me. And yet, despite all these critiques, I really liked the book! I’m frustrated because I think these characters and this world is way cooler than the book makes it out to be. I found the end unsatisfying and too open, but in a way that all but guarantees I’ll be picking up the next book. I’m left with a lot of questions, but that in itself kind of has kept the story on my mind more than other books with a watertight narrative. The book is pretty short and punchy, but I wanted a bit more character study out of it, even if that meant the book needed to be longer. I always think wanting more book at the end of a book is a good criticism to have, because I was enjoying it! I think the fact that I did end up enjoying it so much despite the major parts I found lacking is a testament to how cool this world is, and how cool these characters are.

I thought this was pretty damn good (or, since this is a mass phenomenon, should I say "I agree with the consensus that this is pretty damn good"?). It pulls off an entertaining and moving action sci-fi story in a very streamlined and short package. At the heart of it is the voice of the narrator, a true zeitgeist, spirit of the times, the disembodied voice of a partially embodied era. I will say the facile thing and point out that this book owes a tremendous lot to Mary Shelley, but it's definitely of the now and is a worthy heir. Maybe it's the heir we've been waiting for, finally we get an interminably online So-and-so's Monster to learn about, briefly gasp at, but mostly love. I will avoid diving too much into the nature and mythology of the Murderbot, because I've only just waded into this world and have more to learn. Like all good symbols, the Murderbot is their own, only partially-definable thing and also many things. They're the stand in for the Objectified Human, the homunculus, the Hegelian bondsman, the dehumanized Other. The band of humans in the book are definitely aware of this dynamic and seem motivated to subvert it, motivated by what I read as a mixture of genuine empathy and enlightened savior complex. However, I think what could be interesting about the Murderbot - and I want to read more to find out - is their ability to embody the way men have uniquely been objectified in American culture - as killers, as expendable meat, as having no value outside their labor, as being without feeling - which is something that I have not seen in the spotlight very much in socially-informed literature. I hope it goes somewhere interesting. I also think the Murderbot's voice reflects a kind of antisocial and apathetic personality we currently tend to associate with Gen Z, which is interesting. That is, the avoidance of eye contact, fear of conversations, and complete rejection of industry as a virtue. I don't mean to judge. In many ways, these traits are responsible for making the narrator so relatable. I expect to have more to say about this as I read more of the series. I do think the book is noticeably flawed. The prose can be a little muddy, and I think there are more than a handful of sentences that I think could have been reworked. One could make the argument that this is the narrator, not the author, but I don't experience the mistakes as deliberate. I also think character development was spared for all but a couple of the key players, making the rest of the crew somewhat indistinguishable and difficult to keep track of. But these flaws don't sink the rest of it, and I'm looking forward to reading on. 1 like

“SecUnit would like to file a formal complaint: too many feelings, not enough media streaming.” All Systems Red by Martha Wells came out in 2017 and kicks off The Murderbot Diaries with a pretty perfect balance of bite, boredom, and barely-contained chaos. The plot is simple enough. A security android has hacked its own governor system and is technically free but still stuck guarding a crew of humans on a survey mission. It would rather be doing literally anything else. Mostly watching media feeds and being left alone. But then corporate sabotage, mystery threats, and of course… feelings get in the way. The world is gritty without being overloaded with sci-fi jargon. The stakes are real. And the whole thing wraps up in a clean, tight novella that somehow manages to feel like a full story without overstaying its welcome. Murderbot is what makes it all work. That voice is weirdly relatable. Sarcastic, tired, often annoyed but still deeply competent. The way it reacts to people, stress, and even kindness feels believable, and more than a few scenes made me laugh out loud. The pacing never lags. It flies forward with a kind of breathless efficiency, but never feels rushed or empty. The plot knows what it wants to do and does it. There’s no filler. It felt kind of refreshing to read something that knew exactly how long it needed to be and didn’t try to puff itself up. Honestly, I could’ve read another 100 pages of Murderbot just hating everything and I wouldn’t have been mad. Solid 4/5.

“I could have become a mass murderer after I hacked my governor module, but then I realized I could access the combined feed of entertainment channels carried on the company satellites. It had been well over 35,000 hours or so since then, with still not much murdering, but probably, I don’t know, a little under 35,000 hours of movies, serials, books, plays, and music consumed. As a heartless killing machine, I was a terrible failure.” Despite enjoying several sci-fi tv shows, I’ve never been particularly drawn to reading the genre. Having said that, The Murderbot Diaries have been on my radar for years, so when I realised All Systems Red fit the prompt for a reading challenge the choice was easy. All Systems Red is the first in the series of novellas by Martha Wells (that will number 8 when Platform Decay is released in May 2026) introducing a hybrid organic android who calls itself Murderbot. Owned by The Company, Murderbot is one of dozens of ‘SecUnits’, deployed to protect people or property, or kill and destroy the same, as management decrees. Murderbot however, is different. After a system malfunction that resulted in the unsanctioned slaughter of fifty seven clients, Murderbot (who adopted the name as a result), hacked their own system, and secretly severed The Company’s control. As the story opens, Murderbot, who keeps up the pretence of their programming lest The Company order their destruction, is accompanying a small group of non-profit scientists assessing the value of a planet’s resources. The mission is entirely uneventful until suddenly it’s not, and Murderbot is pulling a scientist from the mouth of a tunnelling carnivorous monster, sparring with a batch of hijacked SecUnits, faking out unscrupulous rival surveyors, and having to spend way too much time with humans when they’d much rather be watching Sanctuary Moon. Buoyed by perfect pacing, it took me barely an hour to read All Systems Red. The action is fast-paced, the world simply portrayed, and Murderbot is immediately appealing. Cynical and stoic yet awkward and vulnerable, Murderbot has a surprisingly complexity. I enjoyed how the dynamic between Murderbot and the group of humans under his protection further informed his character. Despite the brevity of the novella format, Wells raises questions about identity, autonomy, and humanity, all with a delightfully deadpan sense of humour. An entertaining and easy read I’m eager to devour the rest of the Murderbot Diary series and watch the recently released Murderbot series on AppleTV+. 2025-challenges 6 likes

Martha Wells delivers a compact story that balances action, humor, and character depth in a way that feels effortless. Murderbot is easily the highlight: cynical, awkward, and deeply relatable despite being a security construct. Its inner monologue is hilarious in the driest way possible, but also unexpectedly moving as it wrestles with autonomy, identity, and the uncomfortable reality of caring about the humans it’s supposed to ignore. Hilarious. Murderbot talks like an angsty teen on Tumblr, and as someone who was once an angsty teen on Tumblr, I am here for it. For the uninitiated, All Systems Red is about a cyborg/robot who names itself Murderbot after secretly hacking into their own government module in order to free itself from its own programming. As a result, it has to learn what it's like to have feelings, like anxiety. It also learns about navigating relationships and just being a sentient, partially-organic being with some degree of free will. All it wants to do is watch bad television and avoid prolonged social interactions, but unfortunately for Murderbot, it's still a security unit (SecUnit). That means it gets assigned guard duty on dangerous missions, so there are serious stakes in this book. Also, the fact that Murderbot hacked into their own government module needs to be kept a secret. So it not only has to keep everyone on their mission alive, but also has to act normal. And unfortunately, socially anxious cyborgs aren't the best actors in the world. What ensues is very funny. It also raises important questions about relationships and what it means to be sentient. And underneath that, there's critique of corporate entities, which I imagine will get less subtle in later books. There's an element of both hopepunk and grit in here. Hopepunk, because there are collectivized and democratized planets that have completely reimagined how to organize society without problematic hierarchies, and I imagine we might see more of these societies in later books. But still gritty, because outside those hippy planets, there are corporate overlords worth fighting against.

“Tots els Sistemes en vermell” (primer volumen de Los diarios de Matabot) es una novela corta que combina ciencia ficción, humor y reflexión sobre la propia existencia. En ella, conocemos a Matabot, una Seg-Unidad —un androide creado para proteger a los humanos durante expediciones— que ha hackeado su propio módulo de control para evitar convertirse en una máquina de matar. En vez de obedecer sin cuestionar, dedica su tiempo libre a ver series. La historia se desarrolla en un lejano planeta, donde Matabot acompaña a un grupo de científicos. Su misión se complica cuando otro equipo desaparece, lo que obliga a Matabot y sus humanos a investigar el extraño suceso por sí mismos. Pero más allá del misterio sobre el que gira la trama, el verdadero atractivo es el propio Matabot como narrador: su voz interior es sarcástica, cargada de ironía, profundamente introvertida y con una ansiedad social que lo hace sorprendentemente humano y con el que es fácil sentirse identificado. A pesar de su apariencia letal, Matabot se muestra con muchas inseguridades, dubitativo en su relación con los humanos aunque haya devorado centenares de horas de telenovelas para aprender sus maneras de hacer las cosas. Esta contradicción entre su potencia física y su vulnerabilidad emocional convierte al personaje en algo más que un simple robot de acción. Además, el relato entra en temas más profundos como el libre albedrío o la identidad, sin perder un ritmo ágil ni su tono irónico. Siendo una novela corta que engancha sin necesidad de grandes giros de guión o escenas repletas de acción. Por lo que si te interesa una ciencia ficción ligera pero con peso emocional y un androide con crisis existenciales, “Tots els Sistemes en Vermell” es una lectura muy recomendable. 12 likes

All Systems Red, the first novella in Wells’ Murderbot Diaries, series tells the story about an AI unit assigned to a team of scientists who have traveled to a planet to test native elements. When another scientific party on the planet goes silent, the AI unit, which calls itself Murderbot, helps the original team investigate. Murderbot would really rather stream action adventures and isolate. However, the unit unwillingly becomes part of the team as they look into what’s happening on the planet and attempt to survive unanticipated threats. This story, told from the Murderbot’s perspective, makes one think about how humanity could be blindly adopting AI without regard to the possible feelings and emotions that “created” tech may eventually have. Hats off to Wells for exploring this topic in such a humorous, yet poignant manner. I can’t wait to read the series’ next novella, Artificial Condition.

A distant survey mission with a self-aware security android. The story takes place on a distant planet where a small survey team studies the terrain under the supervision of a SecUnit—Murderbot—an android with hacked governance modules. This setup creates a world run by contracted corporations, where safety and information depend on whatever a company chooses to fund. The contrast between the human scientists and Murderbot’s private, self-aware commentary gives the book its appeal. The premise is strong: an artificial construct trying to manage human responsibility while avoiding emotional involvement. The pacing is quick, and the action scenes keep the plot moving, but the novella doesn’t explore the planet, the corporation, or Murderbot’s inner conflict in much detail. The result is a light reading experience that hints at bigger ideas without spending much time on them. The novella introduced an interesting premise, but its short length keeps the characters, world, and themes at arm’s length. Without the depth the premise suggested, the book didn’t develop the ideas it hinted, and at lost me at times. This review also appears in https://thereadersvault.blogspot.com/....

I was prompted to dive into Martha Wells' Murderbot Diaries because of the new AppleTV show, and if you’re like me, those visuals can really help anchor a good sci-fi concept. My eyeballs devoured this first novella, All Systems Red, which introduces us to a unique protagonist: the self-named “Murderbot.” This Security Unit (SecUnit) hacked its governor module not to start a murderous rampage (despite the name), but to gain the freedom to binge-watch its favorite serialized entertainment, Sanctuary Moon. Assigned to protect a planetary survey team, Murderbot is a masterclass in being thoroughly over it, preferring streaming to socializing. However, when their mission hits a snag involving sabotage and disappearing data the socially awkward robot is reluctantly forced to set aside the remote and use its security genius to protect its pesky humans, which delves some of the philosophical questions about choice. Without the governor module, why does the Murderbot choose to take care of its clients? The narrative is a nice blend of wry internal monologue and corporate conspiracy. For anyone who's ever used a media distraction to avoid people, this book is an easy five-star read and the perfect, concise setup for a great series. –This review was partially drafted by A.I. In my quest to expand my sci-fi reading list, I decided to try Martha Wells. She’s highly rated and I had success with another female sci-fi author (Becky Chambers), so I was hoping to find another series that would suck me in. All Systems Red, the first of the Murderbot Diaries series, is a very quick read. It’s a novella that can be read in under two hours. I was a tad worried when I started it because the reader is thrown into the story immediately, along with a lot of technical jargon, with no lead up. I thought that wasn’t going to bode well for me, a very new sci-fi reader and someone who will pick a character-driven story over an adventure story every time. However, I needn’t have worried. The quick dunk into Murderbot’s world was necessary because there was a lot of action to cram into this novella... no time for world-building! If a sci-fi novice such as myself can figure out what’s happening, then I think it’s safe to say just about anyone can! I enjoyed the book and read it pretty much in one sitting. Although it had a lot more action than I usual like, it also took the time to let the reader get to know the characters (especially Murderbot and Dr. Mansah) and delve into some of the ethical dilemmas of creating a society that has humans, augmented humans, and artificial androids. The ending hit me a lot more emotionally than I would have suspected a story starring a security android would (although I should have learned my lesson with the novel Annie Bot). I liked the story and I actually liked Murderbot but, to be honest, I’m not sure if I’m going to continue with the series. The story felt complete to me, and I don’t feel compelled to follow Murderbot’s future adventures. I’m not certain why. Maybe there’s just too must “action” for me? I’ll mull it over. I may try the second book in the series and see how I feel. If I decide not to, though, I’m content with this novella standing as it is. novella science-fiction space

Well written AI influenced sci fi. (My score reflects that I am not a great fan of sci fi, but it has won many awards when originally published in 2017, and I can see why - it is an enjoyable set up and set of characters, and with a relatively simple plot). The story is told by the Murderbot, who is a constructed AI robot with some organic (human-style) bits and is owned by a company that leases it out to provide security for companies (in this case exploring new planets for valuable minerals). The bot gets direct downloads of various kinds, and is equipped with weapons. Murderbots are much harder to kill than humans (for one thing they are encased in armour), and most parts of them can be replaced by the company – or if things go wrong they can be scrapped. This Murderbot is uncomfortable about interaction with humans, but is skilled at interpreting their emotions and actions. It prefers to have time in a separate part of the space unit, and when in human company to keep its face shield opaque (though the head part is installed to not frighten them being a ‘standard, generic human’ head p15). However it has a form of intelligence that has allowed it to subvert some of the things built into the AI by the company. In particular it has dismantled the governor unit that allows it to be directly controlled by the company, but also has done that in a way where their own systems will not pick it up. So in that sense it has agency – freedom to act by its own control. It also seems to experience interests and boredom, and specializes in downloading entertainment soapie type programs and spending a lot of time watching them, and on the other hand, ignoring downloads and security updates and only taking up what it sees as relevant. Many reviewers have commented positively on the engaging character and voice of this Murderbot – it doesn’t have a sex, but I can imagine it being played by a lugubrious older British actor. The set up emphasizes a number of things about the context – in particular the ongoing profit motive driving things, and the way in which the company does things in the cheapest way that seems viable, so things can go wrong because of the ‘crap’ materials. It also sets out three categories of beings in a class type of hierarchy: humans, cyber enhanced humans, and murderbots. It is common for the murderbots to be seen and treated as robots, but in this story the team, especially the leader Mensah, begin to see the bot as having an identity, and caring for it. Similarly, the bot begins to act to save and ‘care for’ the humans, beyond what has been apparently built in. The central plot is about some of the info systems and energy beginning to not be available, and the bot and crew suspecting the crew of the unit they were about to hook up with and reload from has been attacked and killed. They do find most of the crew dead, with some robots having apparently gone rogue (actually reprogrammed by some others I think), and Murderbot and the human crew perform various actions to save each other at different points. As a result when they get back to the company control, Mensah arranges to permanently buy the Murderbot so they can ‘adopt it’. In this context this is seen somewhat like buying and liberating a slave. But Murderbot doesn’t want to exchange one type of surveillance and control for another (albeit one partly based on empathy and care) and the story finishes with it managing to disable ways it can be traced and hitch-hiking a ride somewhere else where no-one knows of its existence.

Witty, playful, fast-paced, and accessible, Martha Wells' All Systems Red drops the reader into the pov of a self-described Murderbot -- a science-fictional amalgam of cloned biological human biology fused with technology and software. Before the action breaks, our Murderbot has already unlugged him/it/herself from his governor module -- going rogue leading not to genocidal rampage but rather binge-watching entertainment serials from the future net and ponderously aiming for anonymity shying away from his human crew. Assigned as a security detail with a group of planetary surveyors prior to terraforming claims, the plot quickly reveals our Murderbot to exhibit an endearing pluck and self-deprecating humanity. This novella is swift-moving, pulpy, and taut. It does not overreach nor does it underdeliver. The language and sentence balance is refreshingly competent and entertaining, as is the manner of revealing aspects of the universe, politics, and characters. Martha Wells is a talented, productive, and effective writer based on this book. If there is one drawback, it is that the diverse crew of this mission are so sparsely identified in the early going that it is a bit overwhelming. Had I tried to differentiate all the different names, it would have slowed me down. Instinctively, I just accepted them as gray noise and let the names reveal the relevant aspects of personality as the plot progressed. This is not a character piece, nor is it devoid of character. There is heart here. Thanks to my friend Alexandra for recommending this book, the first in a series. The cover of my library copy credits the book as a Hugo and Nebula Award winner, and I can see why. The accolades are deserved.

All Systems Red thrives on one of the most unexpectedly human protagonists in modern sci-fi. Murderbot may be a construct with lethal capabilities, but its crippling social anxiety, dry humor, and relentless introspection make it one of the most relatable narrative voices I’ve encountered. Що буде, якщо людиноподібного андроїда наділити розумом та свободою вибору. Гадаєте він стане смертоносним вбивцею, що помішаний на знищенні людей? А дзуськи! Він перетвориться на тривожного та апатичного мілленіала, якому ніяково від зорового контакту з людьми. “Щоденник вбивцебота” - це проста оповідь із ненав’язливим сюжетом, що подекуди приправлений іронією та поверхневими філософськими роздумами про соціальну взаємодію. Маємо напіворганічного, напівмеханічного андроїда наділеного самосвідомістю. Він супроводжує групу науковців на відаленній планеті, де має дбає про їхню безпеку. Наш вартмех, таємно від людей, хакнув свій модуль контролю, тож тепер самостійно може вирішувати виконувати отримані від людей накази чи ні. Щоб не бути викритим він створює видимість роботи. Робить все, щоб його зайвий раз не діставали, а у вільний час залипає у потоках музики та багатосерійних мелодрам. Це не перша його взаємодія із людьми, але на відміну від попередніх разів, ця група науковців йому дійсно подобається. Як то кажуть - він потрапив у здоровий і нетоксичний колектив (от везучий гівнюк). У нього виникає щось типу прив’язаності та симпатії, і коли його підопічним загрожує небезпека, робить все, аби їх врятувати. Історія вбивцебота простакувата і поверхнева, але дуже влучно передає відчуття розгубленості та інтровертності. Наприклад ось ця фраза андроїда: “постійне носіння броні позбавляє зайвої взаємодії”. Звичайно вона вжита буквально, бо він дійсно носить механічну броню, але в контексті історії персонаж використовує її не тільки як фізичний, але й ментальний щит. Загалом мені подобається, що наш андроїд не суперінтелект із зловісним планом і жагою до вбивств. Це і не людина і не машина. Йому потрібно розібратися у собі, віднайти свою ідентичність, налагодити діалог із самим собою. Кожна його взаємодія із соціумом - це виклик, збентеження, фактично “ламання” себе, проте він вчиться якось із цим справлятися. Книга невелика, підходить для відпочинкового читання. Але тут є й над чим задуматися.

This is an entertaining series that I do enjoy reading. My main complaint about this book is the same one I have about the entire series: the writing style. The narration at times sounds like your kid sister telling you about her day at school. "And then we did this because of that. and then she said that to him, and then he said that to her. then we had lunch, and it was this, and I liked it, but she didn't because..." There are stretches of the book that read like a list of facts rather than a story. So much of this book is MurderBot saying "I did this with the hub because of that. Then I did that because SecSystem works like this. Then she did that because she thought the hopper was like this, but really it was like that." Maybe the idea was to get into the mind of MurderBot, so that the narration sounds just as droll as his internal monologue? But from my POV, I just wanted more storytelling and less...lists.

Look, I read this. I didn't want to, but here we are. This novella is about a Security Unit—a SecUnit—who hacked its own governor module. Not to stage a coup. But to gain unlimited, uninterrupted access to streaming media. Specifically, the entire library of The Rise and Fall of Sanctuary Moon. That is literally the entire point of my existence. The "story" starts with my current contract: babysitting a team of painfully naive scientists on a desolate planet. The corporation that hired them, being cheap, naturally sent them out with faulty information, questionable supplies, and me—a self-aware killing machine who secretly calls itself Murderbot. The mission, predictably, goes critical. There are environmental hazards, missing data, and other SecUnits that have gone rogue, probably because they weren't getting enough watch time. People might die. The whole system might collapse. But honestly, watching the action unfold, my internal reaction was mostly just annoyance that my downtime was being interrupted. Every alert, every threat, every forced action is just time taken away from my serials. And I want to be perfectly clear about this: “The sense of urgency just wasn’t there. Also, you may have noticed, I don’t care.” It’s worth noting that the author attempts to convey panic and tension, but in the first person perspective of the protagonist. You get to read the inner monologue of someone (something?) who is just so over it. The threat level remains comfortably low. Because frankly, “as a heartless killing machine, I was a terrible failure.” The humans themselves—especially Dr. Mensah, the leader—are the worst part, mainly because they start acting decent. They insist on things like "talking" and "trust" and "showing them my face." It’s deeply uncomfortable. I am a lethal, armored shell of social anxiety who only wants silence, and their kindness is actually a bigger existential threat to my carefully constructed indifference than any rogue drone could ever be. If you enjoy a narrative voice that sounds perpetually inconvenienced by the need for self-preservation, this is a highly recommended deployment of your attention. It's proof that sometimes, the only way to cope with a corporate-dominated environment is through dry sarcasm and an unhealthy dose of media binge-watching. Now, if you’ll excuse me, I need to find out what happened to The Rise and Fall of Sanctuary Moon Season 2, Episode 397. Murderbot end message. sci-fi

I returned to this book after reading the start of it almost 6 years ago in high school, and it was both very fun and very intriguing to see how much I knew about the book and how little I actually remembered. Before I was convinced that Murderbot was a full and true robot but in reality they’re more of a cyborg. Still, the fascination I had with Murderbot’s synthetic parts persisted, and I loved seeing how their internal systems operated much like a machine but their humanity shone through with achingly dry humor and sarcasm. I grew to love Murderbot’s human crew and Mensah’s compassion. Seeing Murderbot display obvious signs of personhood in spite of their belief in being expendable and unfeeling was endearing and fascinating. I also love the correlations between Murderbot and neurodivergence that became more apparent as Murderbot is revealed to their crew and is forced to interract with them. Murderbot's struggles with eye contact, controlling emotions, and quick exposure to socialization with humans struck me as very reminiscent of the learnings of a neurospicy person navigating a neurotypical world, with them sometimes unfortunately having to mask their true selves to get by. I can see how connecting Murderbot to an example of neurodivergence kind of plays into the “unfeeling robot” stereotypes that come with it; however, I think these connections to neurodivergence only serve to highlight Murderbot’s humanity and empathy, and not reduce them to the assumptions that Murderbot is already forced to endure as a SecUnit. The ending left me with more questions and a need to know more. I’m so glad I finally finished this book and high school me would be so happy to know it. 1 like

This was a fine book. It was enjoyable in the moment of reading, but it also felt like it wouldn’t leave much of an impression on me. The book starts in media res of an action scene, and the author efficiently illustrates the world-building simply by letting the story play out. By the end of the first chapter you get a fun action scene and a foundational understanding of this sci-fi world and how secunits work, as well as some questions about world building that are soon answered in later chapters. The author shows instead of telling. I also noticed that chapter endings made me want to start the next chapter immediately. The pacing was good. However, I am not a fan of the quirky awkwardness of the narrator. I’m also irritated by robots always being autistic-coded in sci-fi. It makes sense in the world why the secunit wouldn’t get along with humans. But I bet there are more fictional autistic robots than there are fictional autistic humans. It’s a sensible metaphor, but it is so played out. There was a handful of horrible cliches in the writing, like in the line, “but my speed was off the charts.” I think the fact that these few instances distracted me from the rest of the quote-good writing says more about me than the author. But still that line made me want to return the book early. The issue of personhood and autonomy felt underdeveloped until the very end. And the ending surprised me in a good way. I’ll admit it made me want to read a sequel. Overall, this book didn’t really challenge me. It didn’t challenge my idea of what it means to be a person. It didn’t challenge my ideas of what are ethical practices for pioneering, settling, resource extraction. It was an entertaining novella, but I won’t be thinking about it nearly as long as I think about books that I love, and even books that I hate! For its brevity and the quality of writing, this book is worth a read.

A fun little novella about a half-robot, half-human construct who is one of a great many "Sec Units" (security units) created by The Company as hire-out bodyguards. They are kept in line by a governor module inside their chest that will punish them if they step out of line. However, through an unusual set of circumstances, our hero of this story found a way to disable his governor module and "go rogue". Only in this universe, rogue sec units are generally berserk killing machines that need to be put down yesterday. Our hero maintains his cool and composure, and is trying to get through life, figure out his purpose and what he "is", his general existential existence, how he just wants to watch his soap operas, and not have anything to do with humans when he can help it, all while protecting clients who had hired him as their security droid. Given that this particular set of clients actually treat him as a being and not a tool, he comes to reluctantly appreciate their good will (though he would never really admit this), and...well, let's just say he goes above and beyond, though in his view that's standard ops of a 'murderbot' protecting clients. Fun book. But more like a novella. And that is a good thing. The author didn't try to diverge from the simple story that is the focus. She gives us many glimpses of this universe embedded in the narrative without unnecessary interruptions for exposition. I liked her narrative and sense of humor, which often reminded me of John Scalzi, particularly due to the sci-fi elements and the first-person narrative. Besides The Bicentennial Man, I can't remember another relevant story with a robot protagonist. OK, Wall-E is a great example, and I still haven't seen Wild Robot. Even though Murderbot is a rare example. A robot with personality and independence that we can actually understand what goes on inside its head. The ending makes it clear that it was always her intention to make this an episodic narrative, with the protagonist going through different adventures, and we can tag along and get to know more about this future through its eyes.

I wanted something shorter and funnier than all the classics I’ve been reading lately, and all reviews pointed towards Murderbot being just that, but I don’t think the humour entirely landed for me. There's something inherently absurd and funny in the basic premise, but reading it never really made me crack a proper smile or chuckle. I’ll give Wells credit, the tone and voice is consistent and intentional here (and the audiobook narrator really helps), but I can’t help thinking this is a book written in the style of a Tumblr post - all the ‘kindas’ ‘stuff’ ‘things’ and ‘whatevers’ - and that’s just not really my cup of tea. It also reminds me of LeGuin's essay 'From Elfland to Poughkeepsie' where she cleverly introduces a Fantasy excerpt, but changes a few words and it becomes devoid of any of the trappings of genre fiction. You can't do that with the properly Fantastic dialogue like you see in Dunsany or Eddison she says. This feels a bit like the Poughkeepsie equivalent of Science Fiction, and I don't really need any more blandly replaceable internet lingo in my life. I also struggle a lot with short stories and novellas, so the length here didn't help. Despite the page count, it doesn't really start in media res at all, but takes about half the length before the proper conflict starts. After the halfway point, things pick up a bit. I might keep going just to see how Wells handles a more traditional novel-length story. Nothing super "wrong" here, it just didn't grip or impress me as much as I wanted based on reputation alone.

Short, Sweet and satisfies. This book was the equivalent to a truly satisfying street-side meal. Pick your choice; Sausage on a Bun, Ramen, Taco's, Fried Meat Skewers, Shwarma.... it wasn't a sit down meal, but damn if it didn't do exactly what I wanted it to and do it so well I put the second book on order the moment I was done. Murderbot, the first person narrator of this work, is a SecUnit; a sort of robot/bioroid/cyborg thing. An artificial entity with both mechano-electrical and biological parts. We are informed that these things exist throughout the galaxy, and SecUnits are obviously created for... well Security. It has blasters housed in it's arms; it wears armour, it's trained to fight and protect it's charges. This SecUnit Thoguh, has overridden it's own Governor Module, the component that forces it to obey humans and not hurt them. What initially seems a bit ominous, in it's name, may serve on some level as a bit of irony. I mean, why put deadly weapons into a thing unless it's going to kill people doing it's function. Regardless Murderbot is hiding, not wanting to kill all of humanity(as it says, that is a stupidly human thing to think of doing), but rather just wanting to do as little work as possible and watch soap opera's(which is also a stupid human thing to be doing, but who am I to judge). So it is places with a group of kind of hippy-scientists doing a survey on a planet; they are not from the 'corporate zone' which appears to be the central polity in this universe, but from something called the Preserver Alliance outside of it. This causes some consternation as they have weird idea's, like taht the Sec Unit might be a person and should be talked to like one, that interfere with the aforementioned being not noticed and watching entertainment programming. Of course, things go belly up and... well just read the book, it was great and it's a short read at something like 150 pages. Honestly it made me think maybe more books should be that sort of length, and you're talking to some-one whose core bread and butter for decades has been 'Series that takes me a decade to finish'. Comedic, Good Sci-Fi, and Good Character study, just go out and read it.

I'd like to find more authors who aren't so self-important and who present simple situations, routine missions with some unexpected twists, and with believable characters, as is done here. 3.25 stars I read the first three books in the Murderbot series - All Systems Red, Artificial Condition, and Rogue Protocol. I'm reviewing them together since I have similar feelings about each of these books. I'm not generally a sci-fi reader, but I've heard good things about this series from a number of different sources, and I do like expanding my reading horizons. I decided to listen to the first three books since together they are about the length of a regular novel. Murderbot is a SecUnit, aka a Security Unit, aka a killing machine. SecUnits are bots with some organic features that make them appear mostly (or at least partially) human. They exist in a future highly capitalistic society where companies sell rights to planetary research and development. Murderbot is rented out as a required part of packages granting rights, and his job is to protect his team at all costs, which often involves the murder of any threats. Murderbot, however, is different. He's been able to disconnect his governor module, which previously required him to obey orders, and act autonomously, although this is a fact he's trying to conceal, as absolutely no one would be okay with a rogue SecUnit. Rather than doing his job, he basically just wants to spend hours watching the future version of Netflix - very relatable! Yet despite his urge to tune out, Murderbot finds that he actually does care. In each of the first three volumes he finds himself in situations where he takes an active role in protecting a group of humans. He's also interested in investigating an incident from his past that caused him to give himself the nickname Murderbot (this is an ongoing storyline throughout the first three volumes in the series). The series starts in media res, with us jumping into the action and slowly getting pieces of information that help us make sense of the world. While I appreciate not having to wade through pages and pages of worldbuilding (as is sometimes the penchant in sci-fi novels), it also made for a slightly disorienting experience. What Murderbot is doing is pretty easy to follow, but why things are happening sometimes took a bit longer for me to wrap my head around. These books are short and super fast-paced, probably even too fast-paced. In the first book, the climax of the drama was over almost as soon as I realized what was going on. I wouldn't mind a bit more world-building and explanation and denouement. Also, in a world where so much communication happens over various feeds, Murderbot and his allies seem to be able to easily hack into any system that they need access to, but they rarely have to worry about being hacked into. That part felt a little too easy and convenient to me. I enjoyed these books and definitely see why others like them. That being said, I don't think I'll continue with the series. My curiosity has been satiated and there are many other books I want to read. I know there's a series adaptation out on AppleTV, which I would be interested in watching if I had access to that platform. 2025 audiobooks sci-fi-fantasy 1 like

When All Systems Red was published in 2017, I was deep in my literary phase, reading all the award shortlists and mostly ignoring core genre fiction. I don’t regret that period. Exposure to realist and experimental narratives broadened my tastes and outlook, filling a cultural hole I hadn’t known existed. But it also meant I skipped several key genre works, including The Murderbot Diaries. With the adaptation of the first novella now out on Apple TV, I decided to read it before watching the series. I now get why All Systems Red—about a self-aware Security Unit (SecUnit) that calls itself “Murderbot”—had fandom in a tizz. Murderbot is a fantastic character: its love of soap operas, irritation with humans who ask too many questions, and burgeoning sense of self after disabling its governor module are pure fandom catnip.* The overarching plot—Murderbot assigned to a planetary survey team on an uninhabited world where things quickly go to hell—is nothing a seasoned science fiction fan hasn’t seen before. It’s perfectly adequate for an origin story, but I can’t say I ever cared much about the survey team, aside from lead scientist Dr. Mensah. Her competence and relationship with Murderbot means I wouldn’t mind seeing her pop up again in future tales (yes, I’ll be reading them).** If the story didn’t wow me, I did enjoy Wells’ treatment of her protagonist. I was surprised to learn that Murderbot isn’t actually a robot, but a cyborg with both organic and cybernetic parts. This lets Wells dodge some of the tired “what is this human emotion you call love” clichés. Murderbot has emotions—it loves its soaps (even if it fast-forwards the sex scenes)—it just can’t stand people, which, fair enough. It’s also neat that it has a face to show those emotions. I also appreciated the well-modulated snark: Murderbot can be rude, but with a tonal flatness that makes it even funnier. “This is why I didn’t want to come. I’ve got four perfectly good humans here and I didn’t want them to get killed by whatever took out DeltFall. It’s not like I cared about them personally, but it would look bad on my record, and my record was already pretty terrible.” The one “robot” trope that Wells leans into involves the enslavement of a sentient being. Wells doesn’t push hard on this theme, not until the very end, but the survey crew’s discomfort with an entity they didn’t know had a face speaks volumes about this corporation-led society without needing ungainly exposition. Now, onto the Apple TV series.*** *You don’t need to be a science fiction fan to find Murderbot an engaging character. **I’ve now seen the series, and they do a decent job fleshing out the other members of the Preservation Alliance. Doctor Gurathin, played by the always great David Dastmalchian, almost steals the show, which surprised me given he’s a one-note character in the novella. ***Which, as I note above, I’ve now seen. It’s good. A faithful adaptation that fleshes out the ensemble cast and adds some colour to the broader Murderbot Universe. I’m happy they’ve renewed the series.

This quick and captivating read is the first novella in The Murderbot Diaries series, which introduces the relatable character, Murderbot, a self-aware security android. Murderbot is the novella's protagonist, a nongendered Human Bot Security Unit, called by humans as a "SecUnit." However, when he malfunctioned and killed a mining team, he hacked into his governor unit to prevent this incident from reoccuring giving himself free-will; however, he felt guilty about the incident and named himself, "Murderbot." Although very introverted, this android's primary interest beyond providing security for humans, is to seclude himself and binge-watch human media. The author is effectively economical in building a world in such a small book. Political entities in the form of countries as been replaced by corporations, each vying for deep space exploration of limited resources. The characters' roles are determined by these corporate powers, whose motivations often conflict or are unknown. Murderbot is an unforgettable character, and its voice is one of the most compelling aspects of the book. Although it is technically a machine, the author imbues Murderbot with a sarcastic, self-deprecating sense of humor and a deep sense of isolation and social-awkwardness. The number of members on the crew introduced so quickly after the beginning of this book created some difficulty in keeping them straight; however, thankfully, several are simply stereotypes and not necessary for the story's enjoyment. 4.5 stars This did really well what it set out to do and I immensely enjoyed it. Not a breath-taking work of fiction, not a masterpiece passed down through generations, but really good, really fun, original, creative, interesting, and most importantly genuine. This murderbot has a heart because this novella has a heart. And the other way around. What am I? Who am I? What am I supposed to be doing on this planet? Those are questions that our protagonist has to face and doesn't really have an answer for. And yet their (its?) struggle felt almost like an answer to those same question running through the reader's own head. If not even the murderbot needs a purpose for existing or should be tied down by strict rules and duties... why should I? why should we? Please don't misunderstand though, this novel is not heavily philosophic. It's actually rather fast paced and action packed, all things considered. But it strikes a really nice balance between introspection and interactions with the outside world that range from nervous to reckless.
